turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Keith Martin, Appellant, versus Herbert Walton, as Probate Judge of Johnson County, Kansas.
Mr. Payne.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, May it please the Court.

This case comes before the Court on this appeal, presenting a matter involving an attorney admitted to the Bar of the State of Kansas and the question that is presented to the Court is whether or not under the Due Process and the Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment, the Constitution of the United States may an attorney who has been regularly admitted to practice in the state of his residence, in this instance, Kansas.

And who also maintains an office and in active practice in that state since the date of his admission be denied by a subsequently promulgated court rules the right to appear as counsel in the courts of Kansas and the Boards and Commissions of that state unless he associates with him, a local lawyer, a local Kansas lawyer.

The same as if he were a nonresident, non-admitted attorney for the sole reason that Mr. Martin, the appellant in this case, in addition to maintaining an office and a practice and being admitted to the Kansas Bar, also maintains an office and a practice in the sister state of Missouri.
That is essentially the question which we have here before the Court today.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: He is a citizen of Kansas?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: He is a citizen, Your Honor, a resident of Kansas, and maintains an office in Kansas.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: He lives there.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: And lives in Kansas, that is correct Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Your reference to the fact that this was a subsequently promulgated regulation or --

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- statute, leads me to ask, approximately what is the size of the Missouri Bar?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: The Missouri Bar as according to the judicial findings of our Supreme Court, is approximately 1800.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The whole state?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: No, in the Kansas City -- Kansas City Missouri Bar.
The whole state, Your Honor, I do not know.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But this is applied to the whole state, does it not?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Well, it applies to Mr. Martin practicing anywhere within any other state so long as he maintains an office in Kansas, our court has said that if he practices in a foreign state also, then he must associate with him when he practices in Kansas, a local lawyer --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I just want to get the incidence of this statute or regulation.
For the whole state, you have given out, I guess, the size of the Bar, roughly what is it?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: In the whole state of Missouri?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Your Honor, I do not know.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Out of the 18 -- within the immediately affected area, out of the 18, how many have a practice both in Kansas and in Missouri?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Well, I think that probably within the so-called classification that is affected by these rules, there are approximately 25 to 40 lawyers who reside in Kansas, who maintain an office in Kansas and who are admitted to the Bar in Kansas, but who also practiced over in Kansas City, Missouri or in the State of Missouri.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not hitting or suggesting that numbers make the difference, I was just curious to know how many lawyers are affected by this -- by this restrictive provision?
You know, out of 15 or 20, did you say?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Well, it would be 25 to 40.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: 25 to 40, who are affected by these rules so far as the area that we are concerned about is concerned.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And that's where -- where the shoe pinches most, doesn’t it?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Well, that is correct, Your Honor.

I think that probably, if Your Honor, if the Court rather understood the geographics of this thing, primarily, this situation arose because of Johnson County Kansas having a largely residential population and having about 90 members of the Bar at Johnson County, Wyandotte County, Kansas, which adjoins Johnson County, having approximately --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor, having approximately all 400 or 500 members of the Bar, and then over across to the east of the state line is Jackson County, Missouri and that is where Kansas City, Missouri is located, and there is approximately 1800 lawyers in Jackson County, Missouri or Kansas City, Missouri.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is there any provision in the law concerning the division of fees?
How they must be divided?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: In the rules?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, in the rules.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Not in the rules adopted, Your Honor, by the Supreme Court.

But each of the local bar associations, the Wyandotte County Bar and the Johnson County Bar, and probably through as far as Jackson County, although we need not necessarily be concerned about that, but Johnson County and Wyandotte County have local rules with regards to fees varying from one-third to 50%.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Irrespective of the service(Inaudible) --

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Well that is the rule, but actually I think most of the counsel, most of the attorneys are guided more or less by the canons adopted by the American Bar Association, in other words it is not an inflexible thing.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When you say rules --?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: The American Bar Association rules, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That is their acceptable rule?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Yes, and I think that is predicated upon the -- or time consumed in the extent of the services and value of the services that may have been rendered.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, this is not (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: That -- that is correct, that's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If it's not the county bar, as a member of (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor, the --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Although they don't know the apparent bar association.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Well, not actually, of course, it depends upon the circumstances and the lawyer involved.

But if a lawyer, a local counsel so-called, insisted that he be paid a minimum fee as adopted by the standard or by the local bar committee, I suppose there would be matter of negotiation between he and the so-called foreign attorney.
But he could insist and probably, the courts would require the payment.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I thought the evidence in this record says that your client (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: All --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is that up to the good conscience of your client to say that (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Well, I know there was some testimony to that effect given by my client in the hearing in the Taylor versus Taylor case.

But actually no lawyer who is compelled to hire a local lawyer expects a local lawyer to sit there and incidentally, I would say to the Court now, that when I talk about a local lawyer being associated, I do not mean a lawyer who merely signs the pleadings in the clerk's office, and then goes back to his office.
Under these rules, that local lawyer, if a case takes a day or 10 days, must be in constant presence of the Court in the court room, and not back at his office.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Payne, I know awfully a little about being – never had any roughly speaking, I don't understand how private arrangement within the Bar of Kansas can determine the fees enforceable in Missouri practice, I don't understand that, except by agreement of party, sure.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Well, Your Honor --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't understand this.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Kansas practice.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Pardon me, sir.
The --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I understand that this involves Missouri practice, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Not, not as far as fees is concerned.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That a Missouri lawyer must associate himself with a -- that a Kansas -- who has office in both states, can't practice in Kansas without associating himself with a Missouri lawyer.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: No.
Your Honors, here --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: -- here is --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- that's what I thought, but I was corrected.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Here is our --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, let me put it this way, I do not see how the internal agreement among the bar association of one state can affect legal business done in another state.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Well, of course, actually the fees that are fixed by the local bar associations of the Kansas counties, do not have any reference to fees that are charged over in Missouri, if I understand Your Honor's question correctly.

But it is only in those instances where a so-called foreign lawyer that is, let's say a Missouri lawyer, comes over into Kansas and under the rules is compelled to hire in association in that lawsuit a Kansas lawyer.
Then under the rules of the county in which he -- this litigation is pending, he must pay to the local counsel a fee.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is -- that is by arrangement within the bar association.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: The bar --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that governing -- is that -- is that --

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: The bar associations of each of the two counties that we're talking about, Wyandotte and Johnson.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, but does that bind your court?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: It has --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In sustaining those fees?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Well, it's never been tested, Your Honor.
No one has ever attempted to say that they could or could not.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: This is, I suppose, a suggested minimum fee schedule.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Which is quite an ordinary (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Which is an ordinary thing, I think, among many of the local bar associations through -- not only Kansas, but other states.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: My point is that if association of a local lawyer for nominal reasons, does that follow that your Supreme Court will also say that if a fellow says, “Yes, I'll hire a Kansas lawyer to sit there or sign his name, but do nothing,” it is a coercive, an unfairly coercive thing for me to be influenced by or guided by the local fees which implied fees for doing business and not merely phenomenal requirement.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Well, I will agree with Your Honor on that statement.
But nonetheless, there are in the two counties involved and in most counties, I believe, a local schedule of minimum fees.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What I'm saying is that our problem isn't tied to the necessity of assuming that this fee scheme also follows from sustaining this promulgated rule.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Well, of course, Your Honor, if I understand the question correctly.
If a so-called foreign lawyer is compelled in this instance, it's Mr. Martin, the appellant here, who as I would like to point out to the Court, ought not be characterized as a foreign lawyer.

But if he hires a local attorney and he's required to do it under the present rules, he of course becomes obligated to remunerate that local attorney, he could not expect a local lawyer to even just sit, as Your Honor has suggested, and not be paid.
Now, how much he ought to be paid is of course regulated so far as the regulation can go by the minimum schedule of fees adopted by the local bar association.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I agree with everything you said except the last sentence.

I do -- do not think -- I do not think until the Supreme Court of Kansas says that any service, any service falls within this minimum fee scheme of the two counties in question, any service, the most nominally subject to it until that is done, I do not think I have to read this promulgation as assimilating the fee scheme of these two counties.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Are there any sanctions for violation of the minimum fee schedule?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Minimum fee?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Minimum fee schedule, yes.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: No, none that I know off, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Not in the bar association or otherwise.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: No, sir.

It is a suggested minimum and of course some lawyers exact it, if that is the proper term, and others negotiate with the foreign -- so-called foreign lawyer, and say, “Well, I've been here two days and my service is worth $150 a day,” it is not an exact thing, it is only a suggestion of minimum fee.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Let me ask you --

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: But in any event, there is of course an obligation on the part of foreign lawyer to pay a local lawyer for his time.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May I ask you this one more question, real quick.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Go ahead.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Suppose your client comes into Kansas to practice law as he could, at least, and under this regulation he has to retain somebody.
Suppose everybody recognizes that he is such a master of a particular litigation in question, if he doesn't need any assistant, he has to comply with the law.
But he says, “I will retain you, but not for the minimum fee.”
And no lawyer in Kansas, in either of these counties, is ready to associate himself on that basis.

And he then goes before your court and said, “I've done my best to comply with your rule,” but no lawyer will serve you except on the basis of an extortion of the fee, what would your Supreme Court say to that?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Well of course, I would not want to speculate Your Honor, about that, it has never occurred, and I hope that it never does.

But I suppose, as I suggested a while ago, that if the local lawyer said to the so-called foreign lawyer, now we have adopted a minimum fee schedule here in Johnson County or Wyandotte County or in Doniphan County or wherever it is.

And if I associate with you, my fee will be the minimum of a third or 50%, I suppose that the foreign lawyer would have no alternative, if he wanted that lawyer other than to -- and of course the local lawyer would be as far as the schedule is concerned, would be within his rights in saying that.
Now, whether our Supreme Court would say that was exacting tribute rather than compensation, I would not argue.
Now, if the Court --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When you referred “the rules” that's the question that I wanted to ask you a while ago, you referred to nothing except the schedule taken by the private bar association or the public, whichever one you want to call it --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- of which has no legal sanctions.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Your Honor, I hope we're not confused on the rules with regarding fees and the rules that are in controversy in this case.

Now the rules that we challenge in this case is not the local bar rules with regards to fees, the rules that we challenge here are rules which we're adopted by the State Supreme Court in December of 1958.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They have the same effect as I understand as a statute?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Your fees do not?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: And that's -- that's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Except that I assume, at least it's been my observation about minimum fees, that if you go to approve a fee before a court, what is a reasonable fee, and you have a standard of that kind fixed by the bar, I assume that would rarely ever be a fee fixed below the minimum.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: That is correct, I think that's --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's the practice.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: That's in practice.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You think that is -- that is the practice?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: In practice, Your Honor is correct about that.
I believe that can be said as true.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And if he is required to hire and he did not fix a fee, that would have to be cut out on the basis of -- you have a quantum myriad action there, they call it action for the value of the services?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Value of the services rendered.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And in that case, lawyers testified to what is the reasonable fee?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: That's correct.

That frequently happens in matters of all probative states and things of that kind that the lawyers are called upon to give expert testimonies to the value of services rendered to the administrator or the executor state.
But --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I assume that the judge would rarely ever fix a fee as below the minimum, that's the reason (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Well, as a practical matter, Your Honor is correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But there's no law (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Most of the local judges are cognizant of the fees that are fixed by the local bar association and in most instances with their approval or at least pass an approval and sanction and so they don't ordinarily go below.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: This is something like a minimum wage fixed by labor unions.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Yes sir.
But the thing which I am not so much concerned myself, at least, with the fee proposition, although that is important in this case.

Is that in 1958, December the 15th, I believe it was in 1958 or about 10 years, after the appellant in this case had been admitted to practice in Kansas and had practiced in Kansas incidentally for all of that period of time.
The Supreme Court of Kansas amended certain rules, rules designated in the brief as Rule 41 and Rule 54.

Now, in the amendment of those rules, the effect of it was that any lawyer although admitted to the Bar in the State of Kansas and although residing in the State of Kansas, and although maintaining an office in the State of Kansas, if he also engaged in practice of law in another state to which bar, he was admitted, then that lawyer that I'm talking about, and it's the appellant in this case, must hire a local lawyer to associate with him whenever he tries a lawsuit or appears before any Commission or tribunal.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Has there been any definition yet by your court of what is meant by engages in the practice of law in another state?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: None, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The scope or the amount of practice or --

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: None, Your Honor and I had hoped to urge that upon this Court, that their -- and it's a little out of context, but it doesn't make a lot of difference.
The term regularly engaged in the practice of law is a confusing thing not only to the appellant in this case, but obviously to all who would think about the term.

Now, would that mean that if Mr. Martin tried two cases a year, or ten cases a year in Missouri under his Missouri license, that a court would say that he was regularly engaged in the practice of law, that is one of the imponderables of this rule and we think for reason of being so indefinite and ambiguous and --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So far as --

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: -- none of certain of ascertainment that it ought to vitiate and strike down these rules that have been --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So far as --

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: -- adopted by the court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So far as your client is concerned, is he regularly engaged in the practice of both states, does he have an office in both states?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.
My client has --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Although he resides -- he resides in Kansas and has a citizenship and voting there.

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: My client resides in Kansas, he maintains a law office in Kansas, he practices in Kansas, and had for 10 years prior to the promulgation of these rules.
Now, he also maintains an office or in the State of Missouri, which is only six to eight miles from where he lives.
He lives at Mission, Kansas and Kansas City, Missouri and he maintains an office in the Bryant Building over there, a matter of six or eight miles to go to his office over there.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Six to eight miles from where he lives?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: From where lives.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: That is correct, that is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I don't see why you emphasize the fact that this law was passed, the rule that was promulgated by your court, whichever you would say, after he went into the practice in both states, why, what do you think that would --

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What weight would that have?

turn.speaker: howard_e_payne
turn.label: Mr. Howard E. Payne
turn.text: In this respect, Your Honor, for 10 years at least, for 10 years from 1940 to 1950, if these rules have any basis at all, it must -- a necessity be predicated upon the competency of the lawyer in an attempt to make lawyers more competent in Kansas.
Now, for 10 years, there was no question with regards to the competency of the qualifications of my client Mr. Martin to practice law in Kansas.

And then almost overnight, Mr. Martin by the promulgation of these rules, and law was placed in the same category as in lawyer who had no license to practice in Kansas who had no residence in Kansas, and who had no office in Kansas, he was placed in that same category.

And I say in the brief I'm -- that I have left that when they do that, take away the competency and the qualification after 10 years of no complaint about, and indeed, there isn't any complaint in anywhere here about Mr. Martin's competency.
The Attorney General of the state has filed a brief in this case and says on page 2, as to his professional qualifications and his personal character, there is no question.

turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
Can he do it by -- can he do it by doing the same thing that this lawyer does by associating with him?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: He can?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: So you make no distinction then between foreign lawyers and lawyers who are admitted to practice in Kansas and who operate as this practitioner does.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You put them all on the same basis.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Could you give us the history of this rule or if it was a law, a statute passed, if you have it.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: There was a --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I assume, it seems to me like it's being argued on reasons that probably not the main reasons, and I don't see why the main reason shouldn't be presented, lawyers and their fee -- and it might be that the state would be interested in their fees --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In preserving their right to get their part of representation.
Who backed this movement before it was – rule was promulgated, who asked for it?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Mr. Justice Black, I cannot answer that.
I came into this case in August of this year.
I do know, and I will say this to you, I do know that there was interest shown by the bar associations after the rules were passed and when the pinch was felt.
I cannot tell this Court, yay or nay, whether that interest was displayed in the promulgation of these rules.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Of course that -- if they have motive of lawyers to do something, it would necessary to invalidate your law, but I was asking because I think I've noticed recently that there are quite a number of places where the lawyers have been backing movements of this kind, I think right here, and in the city of Washington.
With reference to having people register or not register, but divide up their fees, which is a very understandable motive or desire on the part of the bar.
But it's not limited, is it, to your section on the contrary, this kind of law?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: No, sir.
This -- I do not know of other situations in the United States.
This and we have been speaking here this morning of only the borderline between Kansas and Missouri.
Kansas also borders on Oklahoma.
There's a case from that jurisdiction in my brief showing what can have.
We border on Colorado --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What is --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: We border on --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What is it they can have?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: All right, here, Your Honor, is this situation -- there was a lawyer licensed to practice in Kansas, practice regularly in Oklahoma, he resided in Oklahoma, but to me, residence doesn't mean a lot.
It is one criteria and one thing demanded at many states.
But to me, it has nothing to do with professional competence.
A carpenter can live 80 years in Kansas, and not be qualified to practice law.
This lawyer, relying upon, apparently, upon his knowledge and everyday usage of the law of Oklahoma, came in to Kansas, and he filed his action in the wrong court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That sometimes happened in the state with reference to the --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: I do not --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- the knowledge of the rules (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: I do not say that this is a cure all and end all, Your Honor.
But I do say --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I thought you --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: -- that the Supreme Court of Kansas has a right to expect that beneficial effects will flow from requiring that lawyers who regularly practice outside of the jurisdiction will have associated with them, counsel who regularly practice in the judicial district in which that case is pending.
For this reason, it's mere human nature, but human nature is why we need laws.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: With what I saw, do you -- you're admitted to practice in both states, aren't you?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Kansas and Missouri.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: I am not admitted to practice in Missouri.
Anytime I go to Missouri, I associate local counsel in Missouri.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, you are not associated -- you're not admitted to practice, you would have to --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) in any circumstances.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you shy away from the argument that the state could classify, make a classification in order to protect its lawyers and their rights to fees, on the basis that that's not in the case because you think the others found them.
The rules of referenced to -- or the standards used in determining what denies Equal Protection, are pretty broad.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I don't shy --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I am not saying that that wouldn't be --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: I don't shy --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) wouldn't be a denial, but --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Because what we have in this case, and two or three places in the appellant's brief, the client call was supposed ex post facto judicial notice of the Supreme Court of Kansas.
But in the opinion of that court, what the court says is, that prior to the promulgation of these rules, we took judicial notice, they could not only take judicial notice.

They could do as any other Court does, have judicial conferences and take actual notice of those things that were obstructing, hindering or having a detrimental effect on the administration of the law in Kansas, that was done -- these rules, as Your Honor asked before, these are legislative in nature.
I don't question that at all.
And I don't question that they are subject to the Due Process and Equal Protection Clause.

Being legislative in nature and being promulgated as rules by the court, and not as a decision of the court on a matter before that court, the Supreme Court of Kansas not only had the right, but in my opinion, have the duty to ascertain all they could.
Then, in the opinion, they set out their reasons why they felt that the promulgation of these rules was necessary, and a question was asked --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose they extend it to the county, I suppose, there's ample reason to believe that if the man being tried for defense in a county a hundred miles away from a good lawyer of his own county, said they'll get a better jury trial and a better trial as a whole, if they'd get a man located -- local man, wouldn't it?
Has this been extended to the county?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: No, it has not, Your Honor.
No, it has not.
There is no requirement in that regard though.
When I go to Mr. Payne's county, I sometimes ask Mr. Payne, because I think it's to the advantage of my client.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I couldn't --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes, that's frequently (Voice Overlap), I agree with you.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: But this is not mandatory at all, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Lysaught.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: To say that Mr. Martin or one in his class may do office work counseling and the like, but he is stopped only at the courthouse door, is that too your understanding?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Or the door of Boards and Commission, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now then, what does that do to the Kansas conclusion of competence, saying that he doesn't have competence to handle one class of law business when they admit he has competence to handle law -- other classes or law business.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: I think the Supreme Court of Kansas made that distinction in our opinion, if the Court please, on this reason.

They say the trial work demands instant decisions and Your Honor has tried so many lawsuits that I think you can understand the difference between being before that jury, a new question arising and you must make your decision like that, and examining an abstract or drawing a contract and office where you can take two weeks if you want, too, to look up what the law actually is on the subject if you don't know.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now on this, If Martin had competence to do the latter, is to try cases, the day before this rule was passed like Kansas, did he lose it by the rule?
Therefore, is the really basis for the so-called cause judicial knowledge which Judge Bassler took.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Your Honor, any law or most law, shall we say, are enacted to cure a situation which has come to the attention of the body, whether it be the Congress of the United States, they pass a law which forbids an Act, which may have been perfectly legal three months before.
The law makes it illegal.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, I'm not talking about legality as opposed to illegality.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: I'm talking about competence.

I assume that you'll not be less competent tomorrow than you are today, and I would think that the rule which simply barge you on the basis of competence between today and tomorrow would be wholly arbitrary.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: I think not, Your Honor.

If the body studying those rules has studied them and this legislation, the original legislation on this subject goes back to 1935, and has been changed up until this rule was promulgated December 15 of 1958.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was there legislation?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Had there been legislation previously?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: In 1935, general statute 7104 was enacted by the Kansas legislature.
That applied to foreign attorneys who had not been admitted to the bar.
That was amended in 1947.
In 1958, these rules were adopted.
Subsequently, an attempt was made in the Kansas legislature to avoid the effect of these Court rules.
A bill which was presented to the Kansas legislature is set out in the appellee's brief in this case.
The legislature refused to enact that bill after hearings which included testimony from trial court judges of Kansas, as to what the situations were that these rules were designed to prevent.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But these rules derived from -- or justified as based on or authorized by the 47 statute, weren't they?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Not necessarily Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I mean could they -- could your Supreme Court -- your Supreme Court -- is this the subject matter as to which legislation could control?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: I think that the Supreme Court of Kansas under the constitution of Kansas had the inherent part to pass these rules regardless --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But if you take --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: -- of what the legislature is.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If rules were in conflict with the 47 statute, did it?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It did not think that its rules went beyond or in conflict with the 47 statute.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What was the 47 statute?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If in substance provided, that those attorneys not admitted to our bar, would be required to have local counsel with them when appearing before the Boards and Commissions of our state.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well then, it wouldn't appear to have any bearing on this case at all.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is it because --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Other than -- excuse me.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They're foreign lawyers and they have no right to come in to your state and practice law at all.
So, that wouldn't hardly bear on this subject, would it?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: That is correct except --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: -- that obviously, the court went on and broadened that, because of its experience.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: A question was asked --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Let's move on, by foreign lawyers and the 47th statute, did they mean French advocate, an English barrister?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: And those who are not admitted to the -- not licensed to practice law in Kansas, yes, sir?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They'd be in the same position, wouldn't they, before your courts?
They wouldn't have any --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I believe Mr. Justice Brennan asked a question to Mr. Payne about the difficulty of securing attendance of counsel.
And Mr. Payne answered that the Missouri employers were not dilatory.
I've placed no as such blame on the man because he practices in Missouri at all.
But you have the question, Mr. Justice Brennan, of a man with two masters.
He maintains most of this group now.
There are only a few within this group of 300 who go through the pretence of maintaining the law in Kansas.
The rest of them had only one office.
They are in Missouri during all regular office hours.
And when there is conflict between a setting in the Circuit Court of Jackson County Missouri or a setting in the District Court of Wyandotte or Johnson County, Kansas, the Kansas Court settle.
Our first --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Judge, the Supreme Court of Kansas before promulgating these rules studied these things, it's set out in their opinion.
They took notice of it.
I don't think that it is for this Court under the circumstances of this case to make up its mind whether it should or should not take judicial notice of certifying.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: No, I just think it's our business to determine whether there was any basis for them to do it.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now if Kansas -- has Kansas ever, in any way, impaired except by this rule, Keith Martin's license, its certification of his competence to practice law in Kansas?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: His license is still enforced --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: No, can he use it today?
Can he use it today?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Yes sir, he can use it --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: -- subjects to the limitation --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: -- established in these rules.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: He can use if, can he?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: If he gets another local lawyer to associate with him, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: If he gets a lawyer as defined by statute who resides and maintains his office in the judicial district in which --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Alright, now I can ask you then, why is it he cannot use the license, his Kansas license, to practice law in Kansas without associating with someone else with him, why?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: I will answer that in this manner, if the Court please.

Experience shows that Kansas Court has set out in there, in their opinion that too often, these lawyers who practiced regularly in Missouri, Nebraska, Oklahoma, or Colorado came into the courts of Kansas, and to use a colloquialism, if Your Honor will excuse it, they played it by year.
They regularly practiced over there.
They were accustomed to the procedure over there, so when they came in to Kansas Court, they wouldn't look up to see what the proper procedure was, but assume it was the same as their.
And with regard to this appellant if it please Your Honor, while Mr. Payne says that he is without fault, there is no question of any blemish on him.
That, we are here on a motion to quash so the facts submitted, the facts in well-pleaded in his petition in mandamus are admitted.
But there is a Kansas reported case in which this appellant failed.
He went up on appeal in a criminal case, his client was convicted.
He failed to tender some motion to -- some evidence that has been rejected by the trial court on his motion for new trial.
Now, that's just an oddity we have in Kansas, but if you don't do it, there isn't anything before appellate courts.
He complained that the trial court hadn't given an instruction to the jury.
No instruction was tendered.
Now, I don't know under the procedural law of Missouri, if you must present at your motion for new trial, any evidence which is excluded by the trial court.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: And regularly practice.
Yes sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: And devoted his full time to Kansas practice, yes sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: I don't think you can make it quite that simple, Your Honor.
And the question is and I was amused that the question asked here before, is this to be dealt with regard to only Keith Martin or with the group which falls within the rules promulgated by the court.
I myself have had just a little bit of difficulty in following an appellant's brief just which we are here with.
At times, he finds fault and says that the group established is unreasonable.
Well, that would apply to the entire group.
And then at other places in his brief, he says, “Well, maybe these rules are necessarily for some of these fellows, but I am a man of superior ability.”
And he is, there's no question about that.
“And therefore, they should not be applied to me.”
Well that, if this Court please, and the Supreme Court of Kansas set out to establish a standard on individual ability, I think that would be first thing this Court would strike down.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Lysaught, in answer to Justice Whittaker a moment ago, you said that he would bring himself outside the scope of this rule only if he devoted his full time to the practice law in Kansas.
That's not quite true, is it?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Isn't it true that --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: I overstate.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Just let me ask you this.

Isn't it true that if this appellant spent 95% of his time in the grocery business in St. Louis, Missouri or in Kansas City, Missouri or in the shoe business or around a drug store, or an investment business, or anything else, 95% of the time in Missouri, still he would be entitled to practice law in Kansas anytime he wanted to, without associating a Kansas Lawyer?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Your Honor is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So, he need not devote his full time.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: The only criterion, the only standard is the regular practice of law --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So only, if he has a --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: -- in other jurisdiction --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- only if he practices law in Missouri, that he can (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: He can spend all his or 98% of his time doing almost anything else.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is still not be covered by this rule.

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Your Honor is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And not be under an obligation to associate with a Kansas lawyer.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose this gentleman when he went to try the case with Taylor versus Taylor --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose the gentleman when he had gone to try the case of Taylor versus Taylor out which this seems to be in the beginning, had hired another lawyer like himself who practiced both in Kansas City -- Kansas and Missouri.
Would that have been a local lawyer, could he have associated him?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: No, there is a statutory definition that goes back behind that, Your Honor, in 7104, that the local counsel must both reside and maintain his office and I think that has been extruded --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I assume -- let's suppose --

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: -- his sole office in the judicial district --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Would you say sole office?

turn.speaker: j_donald_lysaught
turn.label: Mr. J. Donald Lysaught
turn.text: I think that has been so construed.
And I think that Mr. Martin in his brief admitted that in substance, he was not authorized to local -- to serve as local counsel under that rule, under that statute.
The statute itself does not use that word, but, I think that the appellant himself has taken the position that that cannot be.
